CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 7, 1950, pg. 4, reads: "Amnesia Victim Cheery While Awaiting Identification - (1) Tom Jackson beams for the cameraman as he ties his shoes. A youth of 17 or 18 years, he found himself wandering through the streets of Clearfield last Sept. 20 unable to remember anything about himself before that date.  (2) The name Tom Jackson was given the youth by Mr. and Mrs. John M. Kachik, administrators of the Clearfield County Home where he was placed by local authorities to await some identification.  Here he shows the Kachiks a model airplane that he has been working on in his spare time.  (3) A youth of average intelligence, Tom is jovial and mixes well with other inmates and outsiders, but often prefers to curl up with a stack of pulp magazines.  (4) When Christmas came at the home Tom was delighted to see the many gifts and decorations under the tree, but he was was more delighted when Melvin Stewart, 23 (center) took him home to Curwenville [Curwensville], Pa. for the holidays.  Melvin's mother, Mrs. P. J. Stewart, has devoted a great deal of her time toward searing for the boy's parents out of sympathy for him and his mother. - Photos by Harris."Related article published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 28, 1950, pg. 17, reads: "Out of the fog - Charles Herbert Jr., Washington (D.C.) high school graduate and athlete, who became an amnesia victim last Sept. 19, while walking along a Washington street, was re-united with his mother, Mrs. Lala Herbert, in tiny Clearfield, Pa., after an amazing experience..."
TitMainTitle: Charles Herbert Jr. seated on cot and tying his shoes, in Clearfield County Home
